title: Amazon promotes cameras with security flaws that leave shoppers exposed to hackers
text:
Amazonis promoting webcams, baby monitors and home surveillance cameras with gaping security flaws which could be used to spy on their customers, the consumer group Which? has found.

Researchers tested six wireless cameras that had received the coveted Amazon's Choice label, driving them to the top of the company's search results, but found serious loopholes including weak passwords and unencrupted data.

Which? had originally been alerted to the devices by reports from industry experts and customers, including one father who reported hearing a strange voice coming from a camera left next to his child's cot which gave him "chills down [his] spine".

The practice of hacking into people's webcams to spy on them, extort them, or sometimes simply torment them for fun, has spread widely in the last decade and is sometimes known as "ratting".

In many cases hackers are able to take over devices because their admin privileges still depend on default, factory-set passwords which are easily available online - a flaw shared by many of the devices that Which? tested.
